enrichment.AboutCourse:
Trainees will complete their year’s training at [Oakthorpe Primary School](https://www.oakthorpe.enfield.sch.uk/), an Ofsted graded ‘outstanding’ school situated in the London Borough of Enfield. \r
\r
The tuition fees for a one year SCITT course with the 2Schools Consortium will be £9,000.\r
\r
All trainees on the 2Schools Consortium SCITT Programme have the opportunity to work towards a PGCE (Primary Education) award which will be validated by the University of East London. \r
\r
SUMMARY\r
SCITT (School Centred Initial Teacher Training) is a school-based route into becoming a qualified teacher and achieving QTS. The course lasts for one year full-time, from September to July. Most of the course is spent in school, where successful applicants are placed in a class under the supervision and guidance of a mentor (often the class teacher or a senior member of the school’s staff). Experience in school progresses from observing and working alongside the class teacher, to taking full responsibility, initially for individuals and groups, and later, for a whole class. All trainees will have experience in at least 2 different key stages and will be placed in contrasting school settings to ensure breadth of experience.\r
\r
TRAINING SESSIONS\r
Training sessions are delivered weekly (during the Autumn and Spring term) in conjunction with trainees on the School Direct salaried programme by a range of experienced teachers, outstanding practitioners and leading figures in their field.\r
\r
ASSESSMENT\r
Assessment of the teaching is carried out regularly through observations of lessons and discussion.  \r
\r
Teaching is assessed against Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) Standards, on three teaching practices across two school placements. \r
\r
A personalised training plan guides the trainee through weekly expectations of their learning through class based activities, tasks and assignments and out of school training.\r
\r
COURSE TIMETABLE\r
Term 1:        \r
4 days per week in consortium school, observing and shadowing class teacher, increasing to teaching 4 sessions per week by the end of term\r
Every Thursday- training all day\r
\r
Term 2:        \r
4 days per week in consortium school in a different KS, then in a different school (contrasting setting) observing and shadowing class teacher, increasing to 3-4 days teaching\r
Most Thursdays- training all day\r
\r
Term 3: \r
5 days teaching up to 85% of the week in main placement school\r
Training will take place up to 3 times over the course of the term.\r
\r
If you would like to find out more or have questions that are not answered, please contact us by [post, phone, fax or email](http://www.2schools.org/contact/).\r
enrichment.Qualifications:
\r
* First Degree of a United Kingdom Higher education institution or equivalent, passed at 2.2 or above\r
\r
* English, Maths and Science GCSE grade 4 or above or the equivalent \r
\r
* Professional Skills Test in Maths and English \r
\r
If your qualifications were awarded abroad, you must submit proof of equivalency from NARIC with your application.
enrichment.InterviewProcess:
Applicants are shortlisted according to a scoring system against our (person specification)[http://www.2schools.org/scitt/what-are-we-looking-for/].\r
Candidates invited to interview must take the numeracy and literacy skills tests and the interview is subject to passing both tests.\r
\r
INTERVIEW DAY\r
Shortlisted candidates are invited to spend the day at Oakthorpe Primary School.\r
The day consists of:\r
Group introduction\r
Tour of the school\r
Half a day in class\r
Reading a story to a class (observed by class teacher/ member of school’s SLT/ Programme Leaders)\r
Interview with up to three members of the management board\r
Internally set Maths and Literacy Tasks\r
Summative assessment by class teacher.\r
Successful applicants are then offered a place subject to:\r
\r
Satisfactory completion of up to 5 days of school experience\r
Satisfactory criminal record (DBS) and health checks\r
Satisfactory references\r
During the 3-5  day school experience, candidates are observed in a variety of situations and by a range of staff.  We look at their approach to teamwork, relationships with staff and children, professionalism, flexibility and initiative during this period.\r
\r
Observations made by class teachers and the training managers, applications, interviews, subject audits, and trainees self-audit of prior experience, all inform the needs analysis and development of a training plan once the candidate is registered on the course.\r
\r
If you would like to find out more or have questions that are not answered, please contact us by post, phone, fax or email.

enrichment.HowSchoolPlacementsWork:
Most of the course is spent in a primary school (3-11), where successful applicants are placed in a class under the supervision and guidance of an experienced and supportive mentor (often the class teacher or a senior member of the school’s staff).\r
\r
Throughout this experience trainees acquire the skills, knowledge and understanding of the range of elements which make an outstanding teacher, as specified in the Teachers’ Standards; from developing good relationships with children that promote learning, with other colleagues to working within a framework and national and school policies to deliver the Curriculum.\r
\r
Experience in school progresses from observing and working alongside the class teacher, to taking full responsibility, initially for individuals and groups, and later, for a whole class.\r
\r
The course will include a minimum of three placements/practices. One of these practices will take place in a partnership school. Our partnership includes around 40 schools across North London. \r
\r
Teaching is assessed against Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) Standards, on three teaching practices across two school placements. Observations and assessments are made by school-based mentors, link tutors and members of the SCITT team. Subject knowledge, pedagogy and a trainee’s development as a reflective practitioner are assessed through a combination of observations, written assignments and evidence files.\r
Course Timetable\r
\r
Term 1:        \r
4 days per week in consortium school, observing and shadowing class teacher, increasing to teaching 4 sessions per week by the end of term\r
Every Thursday- training all day\r
\r
Term 2:        \r
4 days per week in consortium school in a different KS, then in a different school (contrasting setting) observing and shadowing class teacher, increasing to 3-4 days teaching\r
Most Thursdays- training all day\r
\r
Term 3: \r
4-5 days teaching up to 85% of the week in main placement school\r
\r
Training will take place up to 3 times over the course of the term.\r
\r
All trainees will have experience in at least 2 different key stages and will be placed in contrasting school settings to ensure breadth of experience.\r

inst.TrainWithUs:
The 2Schools Consortium consists of a lead school, Oakthorpe Primary School, Enfield, and a number of partnership schools where trainees are placed.\r
\r
Oakthorpe has been successfully involved in teacher training since 2002 and has a wealth of experience in mentoring trainees and in delivering training.\r
\r
All trainees on the 2Schools Consortium School Direct Salaried and SCITT Programme have the opportunity to work towards a PGCE award which will be validated by the University of East London.\r
\r

inst.TrainWithDisability:
At 2Schools we want to enable everyone to reach their full potential. After all teaching is the professions that unlocks potential in children.  If you do have and declare a disability we will do everything we reasonably can to make special arrangements. Please provide details on your application form so that we can ensure this happens. This will not affect your application.\r
\r
We are committed to provide equality and fairness for all in our recruitment and employment practices and not to discriminate on grounds of age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage/civil partnership status, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex, or sexual orientation. We oppose all forms of unlawful and unfair discrimination.\r
\r
We have regularly successfully supported a number of trainee with dyslexia, mental health conditions and learning difficulties and will continue to provide high level of support for any disability.
